definition: Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
surname Kang
healthy/peaceful/abundant
to have/there is/there are/to exist/to be
variant of 為|为[wei4], because of/for/to
because of/for/to
variant of 為|为[wei2]/as (i.e. in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do
as (in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do/by (in the passive voice)

sentences.english: Liang, once a student of Kang's, helped Kang by writing articles propagating reformist ideas.
sentences.chinese: 康有为的学生梁启超协助撰写文章，宣传变法思想。

sentences.english: It will look at the East-West cultural ideologies from Youwei-kang and Yukichi-Fukuzawa's perspectives in the first section.
sentences.chinese: 第一部分主要探讨康有为与福泽谕吉的东西文化观。

sentences.english: The book Jiaoxue Tongyi contains important thoughts of early Kang Youwei.
sentences.chinese: 《教学通义》是康有为早年思想的重要反映。

sentences.english: Kang Youweis view of studies of models of handwriting is an important part of his calligraphic thoughts.
sentences.chinese: 帖学观是碑学大师康有为书学思想的重要组成部分。

sentences.english: Kang Youwei and Liang Qichao narrowly escaped.
sentences.chinese: 康有为和梁启超侥幸逃脱。

sentences.english: Kang with his calligraphy practice, these are not part of the criticism of Kang's book, it also reinforce the criticism.
sentences.chinese: 此外还要结合康有为书学主张与书法实践的矛盾。

definition: Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
the reformist faction
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Hundred Days Reform (1898), failed attempt to reform the Qing dynasty
Hundred Days Reform (1898), failed attempt to reform the Qing dynasty
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
coup by Dowager Empress Cixi 慈禧太后[Ci2 xi3 tai4 hou4] ending the 1898 attempt to reform the Qing dynasty
Zhang Zhidong (1837-1909), prominent politician in late Qing
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Liu Shipei (1884-1919), Chinese anarchist and revolutionary activist
Tan Sitong (1865-1898), Qing writer and politician, one of the Six Gentlemen Martyrs 戊戌六君子 of the unsuccessful reform movement of 1898
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
Guangxu Emperor
Dr Sun Yat-sen (1866-1925), first president of the Republic of China and co-founder of the Guomintang 國民黨|国民党/same as 孫逸仙|孙逸仙
Tang Shaoyi (1862-1939), politician and diplomat
